history.content:
I wanted to respond in addition to the response below just because I felt exactly the same way you did last semester after finishing 61A - I got a B+ in that class as well and despite all my love and respect for someone so inspiring as Prof. DeNero, I was absolutely demoralized and was scared that CS wasn't for me. I didn't have the pressure of declaring, but I felt the fear and disappointment all the same, especially since it often seemed that everyone around me had gotten A+/As with relative ease, and I'd felt like I worked so hard and still didn't reach my goals.

Then the spring semester started, and I went into 61B with Josh Hug. And while I never met him and he'll probably never know who I am, he and that class made me feel at home again, and I wouldn't be surprised if it ends up being the same for you, even with Hilfinger. That class by design is consistently intellectually stimulating and is entirely different from the gimmicky IQ-test style that 61A sometimes took on, often to the point where 61B tests actually were fun. So, tldr, you'll be fine - there's nothing to worry about! You're going to have a blast, even if it gets challenging sometimes. I think reviewing the material and going through the raw content from previous semesters at your own pace is excellent advice, from either professor (I think Hug's videos are more captivating and better in general, but up to you).

Have a great summer, and good luck!

---------------------------------

First of all congratulations on your B+ in CS61a. It's a big achievement to get that grade in 61a and I commend you for your hard work.

Don't be discouraged by your B+ in CS61A. You can definitely still declare CS pretty easily and you still have a long way to go so don't think that you can't declare CS. Hilfinger is known to have much easier exams so your grade is heavily dependent on the projects. I have had lots of friends do extremely well in 61B w/ Hilfinger (get As) just by doing well on the projects. 

If you want to get a head start, I would recommend looking at https://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs61b/fa18/ and studying the content and looking at the projects in advance. Good luck with declaring CS and I hope you have a great summer :)

children.subject: Don't worry at all! I had my worst grade in 61A and things will only get easier from there as long as you are consistent in your hard work.

TL;DR: Watch Hug's lectures and do the vitamins, labs, and (maybe) homework, and even practice midterms. They indeed help. Ask someone (TA or Prof Hug maybe?) to get the skeleton code and use the public autograder linked below.

First, don't be discouraged by the grade. CS61A is indeed a tough course. And whether or not you should do CS should not just depend on a grade from an introductory class.

Here's what I did for CS61A over summer to ensure I could declare CS:

1. Watched every lecture, then did the corresponding labs and HWs (but not projects)

2. Did one or two practice exams (Yes, that helps)

3. Learned everything again during the regular school year (try not to look at your answers written in summer)

Reflections:

1. Because of the extra time I spent on the course in advance, I got to REALLY know the material. And yes, I did learn a lot even when taking the course "again" during the regular school year. IMO, you need multiple exposures to master some tricky materials.

2. I only studied materials up to before MT2 during summer, and there is some noticeable difference between my level of understanding of pre-mt2 and post-mt2 material in the fall. So I think my approach indeed helped.

3. I think spending more time during the regular school year should achieve a similar result. But as Berkeley students, we usually don't have that "more time".

This is also applicable for 61B. Some notes:

1. You may need to ask someone to get the skeleton codes but there's a public autograder available https://sp18.datastructur.es/ (Should show up under Summer 2018 tab)

2. I think reading the textbook without writing any code won't work, at least for a hands-on course like Hilfinger's 61B.

3. I lab assisted 61B this semester and I would say learning the material of 61B again indeed deepened my understanding. Given the importance of 61B, I should probably use the same approach.

4. Of course, this is probably not the most efficient way to prepare but since it should work, you may try it for meeting the GPA cutoff.

B+ in 61a is really good! You’re a legend.

youll get an A in Hilfinger 61b if you get 100%ish on projects.

then all you need in 70 is B- you’re chillen

history.content:
Hi guys, I'm feeling pretty demoralized after getting a B+ in 61A today, and now I'm starting to wonder if CS is even for me and if I can even declare or not.

I'm taking CS61B this fall with hilf, and was wondering what the best possible way to prepare was?

Should I just start watching the lectures and doing the labs? Or should I learn Java first own my own and then jump into reading a DS&A textbook like CLRS or Sedgewick? What is the most efficient way to prepare for this class in advance?

Thanks guys.
history.subject: How to prepare for 61B in advance?
